item.title: Disclaimer
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded: Hold on one cotton-pickin' minute! None of the reviews on this website have been solicited or paid for in any way by the establishments featured on this blog. The advertisements contained on this site will never feature a coffee shop that I have reviewed. This would be unethical and that's not how we do things. This site is designed to be a helpful resource to those looking for a place to try, caffeinate their web experience, or simply explore a new place. That's it. Cheers Folks. Now for the official Disclaimer The information contained in this website is for general information purposes only. The information is provided by CoffeBot and while we endeavour to keep the information up to date and correct, we make no representations or warranties of any kind, express or implied, about the completeness, accuracy, reliability, suitability or availability with respect to the website or the information, products, services, or related graphics contained on the website for any purpose. Any reliance you place on such information is therefore strictly at your own risk. In no event will we be liable for any loss or damage including without limitation, indirect or consequential loss or damage, or any loss or damage whatsoever arising from loss of data or profits arising out of, or in connection with, the use of this website. Through this website you are able to link to other websites which are not under the control of CoffeeBot. We have no control over the nature, content and availability of those sites. The inclusion of any links does not necessarily imply a recommendation or endorse the views expressed within them. Every effort is made to keep the website up and running smoothly. However, CoffeeBot takes no responsibility for, and will not be liable for, the website being temporarily unavailable due to technical issues beyond our control.

item.title: Who is Bot1?
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded: Bot1 is the heart and soul of CoffeeBot. A little odd considering he has neither, but I digress. It was Bot1 who wrangled me, a human, into writing for this blog (writing is completely beneath him, besides, he writes in binary). During the design and building of Bot1, a hapless software engineer spilled his triple half-caf pumpkin latte with extra whip cream across the main circuit board-the the very board that was supposed to be the 'kill center' of the robot. The programmed need to kill became a need to caffeinate and try as they might, they could not re-program the bot. Just as they were about to put him out to pasture, I saw the engineer's for sale ad on craigslist, and spotting his need for all things espresso, I knew I could exploit-I mean, utilize him. It. Bot1. Bot1 is stubborn, single-minded, slightly rude and a lover of all things Pomeranian. He never reboots, always says "excuse me" and consistently compliments me by putting me down. However, without it-him-whatever, this blog couldn't exist.

item.title: Become a CoffeeBot
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[ad#Google Adsense]

Love coffee? Have opinions? Always wanted to be a robot? You might be the right candidate to contribute to CoffeeBot! CoffeeBot is needing witty, talented writers from all over the world who love coffee, appreciate the coffee culture, and love all things unique. You'll get your very own bot designation (i.e. Bot4, Bot2449472) and a warm, fuzzy feeling grounded in the knowledge that you are helping your fellow citizens and travelers find what they need most: a great cup of coffee. Interested? Let me, Bot2, know by sending me a message. [si-contact-form form='1']

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded: It is no secret to those who know me (Bot2) that I really do love coffee. What I’m not sure of, however, is what I love more: the consumable product, or the atmosphere it’s consumed in. The love of the two is my inspiration behind this blog. No false pretenses, no agendas, no long loquacious sentences, just some chatting about coffee and the coffee culture. Ultimately, this site should serve as a resource for people looking for new and exciting coffee shops. Plain and simple. You may be wondering if I even know anything about coffee. Yes, yes I do. Then again, no, no I don’t. In the “yes” camp, I have over 10 years experience working in the coffee business. I built and ran a coffee shop early this millennium and upon moving to a new suburban area, I spent my time working for various shops while going to school. In the “no” camp, I know that coffee is not a stagnant entity easy to sum up. Coffee is more than just 98% water; it’s a culture, a way of life, a multidimensional beverage that changes by the seasons, countries and political uprisings. It is this complex personality that I love about coffee-always changing and morphing, yet somehow staying comfortably familiar regardless the venue in which it's consumed. That's enough about me. The true hero is Bot1

item.title: Two Rivers Coffee
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="4.5" cat1detail="The focus is on the coffee here. Conversation, craftmanship and quality prove that point." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="2" cat2detail="Tables were very uncomfortable and the overall decor left something to be desired. "]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholNo MusicFree ParkingNo FoodFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
7745 Wadsworth Boulevard, Arvada, CO 80003 (303) 424-1313
Website
On a very hot day back in July I came across Two Rivers Coffee. I stumbled in to the quiet, unassuming shop which promptly had me sold when I saw them using the Clover brewing system. Not only that, they served Novo Coffee, a gem in Colorado's roasting crown. That said, it was hot, and I needed something cool. The Coffee The person working there, who I later found out was the owner, convinced me to try what he called a "toddy", or a cold brewed coffee. I say convinced, because I am a pretty staunch hot coffee kind of guy. Bot1 couldn't compute the concept of cold coffee, and already being overheated from the 90 degree outside temps, inadvertently went into hibernate mode before his processor overheated. However, I accepted. The cold brew turned out to be exactly what I needed on that hot day. Unlike other iced coffees that I've had which usually capitalize on overwhelmingly acidic, citrus notes to fool you in to thinking you're being refreshed, there was a general lack of acidity which was replaced with a surprisingly deep, smooth palette of caramel and earth tones. Not at all what I expected from a cold coffee. A hint of spice lingered on my tongue and the aftertaste, despite the overall intensity, was very pleasant. The flavor lasted, as well, and despite being slightly watered down from the ice, my last sip was just as good as the first. I was sold. The AtmosphereAs for the other important aspects to the shop: service and atmosphere, there are a few more notes to ad. Since I was served by the owner, I was immediately engaged in pleasant conversation and was able to talk for a fair amount of time about coffee, asking questions, etc., and he was more than willing to chat. I get the vibe that it's an atmosphere he tries to foster. And, speaking of atmosphere, well, you don't go there for it. The tables were uncomfortable, especially for the lengthy amount of time I was there (waiting on Bot1 to wake up), the blue walls made me nervous, and the local art display, while well-intentioned, was haphazard and not well organized. The End(A note here: this original review was written back in July and I have since seen they are doing some work on the place, so the atmosphere complaint might be a moot point) None of that would keep me from there, however, because this is the kind of coffee shop you go to for the superb coffee, you don't have to go there for anything else. I strongly recommend you go and enjoy some of the highest quality coffee available here at 5,280 feet. END [mappress mapid="2"]

item.title: Paris on the Platte Cafe & Bar
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="3" cat1detail="Utilitarian caffeine with modest attention to quality." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3.5" cat2detail="Dark where it needs to be, light where it's important, local art and aged/warehouse character"]
Features (Key) No ATMAlcoholNo MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
1553 Platte St, Denver, CO 80202 (303) 455-2451
Website
Paris on the Platte is one of my favorite urban coffee bars in the Denver metro. It has all the great 'cool factors': local art that is usually good, a store-front facing a lively street, weathered decor, indie rock (I walked in to Viva Voce playing over the speakers—one of my favorite bands), citizens in skinny jeans, and decent espresso. It's a great place being not only a coffee shop, but also a cafe and bar. The Coffee Bot1 showed up in a pair of skinny jeans he had purchased from the Salvation Army, and after I wrestled them off of him, he sulked up to the counter and ordered a small latte. Even though we ordered a small, it came in a nice big mug, and after some detailed chemical analysis, Bot1 concluded the cinnamon on top of the foam was in fact, cinnamon. A nice touch, but if you don't like people putting spices on your coffee, you might mention that upon ordering. After this, he lost interest, went over to the bar, and I was left to do the tasting by myself. The latte was...good; nothing amazing. The foam was a tad bubbly and I would have liked more espresso presence, but the flavor that was there was smooth and balanced, so I can't really complain. This isn't an artisan place, so I didn't detect much passion for coffee itself; I understand that coffee passion isn't necessarily the point to the place. The Atmosphere The main thing about this joint is that you can come in, set up your lappy, and do what you do best: hit up Facebook. Keep in mind that most people who sit there for a while are also on their laptops, so the connection speed is pretty slow. So, if you're heading there to play Warcraft, it might not be the best place. Then again, you probably wouldn't actually head outside to go to a coffee shop, either. Another great aspect is the presence of living, breathing people (not just spoiled robots), and at this place, the flow of humans is pretty constant. Of all the times I have visited, I've never seen it empty, and I like that. The steady murmur of conversation is the perfect soundtrack to get my work done. It definitely is a neighborhood staple, and you aren't without choices on where to sit or plug in. There's plenty of room in the coffee side, bar side, and there's even a little patio outback where cigarettes tend to be smoked. The End Overall, it's a good place, and I find myself recommending it often. Bot1 even likes it, but I can't be sure the presence of wine next door is not swaying his judgment.END [mappress mapid="1"]

It has all the great 'cool factors': local art that is usually good, a store-front facing a busy, lively street, beaten-up decor, indie rock (I walked in to Viva Voce playing-one of my fav's), citizens in skinny jeans, and decent espresso. It's a unique place being not only a coffee shop, but also a wine bar.

item.title: Forza Coffee
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="3.5" cat1detail="The employees seem to care & their product, and the result is a decent product." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3.5" cat2detail="Lot's of seating, fireplace, power outlets, local art, competent interior design."]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholNo MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
3013 W. 104th Ave., Westminster, CO 80031 (303) 465-0605
Website
I was trying to decide which coffee house to review first for CoffeeBot. Not the most easy decision to make considering here in the Denver metro area we have close to 10 x 8 to the third carry the two coffee shops. OK, not that many, but still. Luckily, Bot1 made the decision for me, and it's a good one: Forza Coffee in Westminster. I know, I know, a suburban coffee shop, but bear with me... The History From what I know about this place, its pedigree is traced back to Tacoma, Washington—not a bad place to come from, I suppose. Their self-description talks of being a vital part of the community and being inspired by Italy's espresso culture, yada yada yada. Nearly everyone says that. Even Howard Schultz said that at one time and look where that got us. However, their expressed desire to be a neighborhood coffee shop seems to actually be working. The Coffee My standard first-time drink is usually an Americano or latte. In this case, the Americano is a wonderful baseline drink. If made correctly, you get a lovely crema, the hot water and espresso combination even out the flavor of the coffee, and let's face it: espresso is gone way too fast. I'm not Italian, for Pete's sake. I love espresso shots but will only drink it straight in places I really trust. To my delight, I heard the familiar banging of portafilters into bins, and I had a feeling I was in for a treat. The drink was produced and brought to my table, whereupon I viewed that nice layer of crema. The flavor was good. Not amazing, but good. The espresso certainly embodied everything a fine espresso should: full body, slight bitterness, subtle caramel tones; but for me, the dimension didn't go far enough. That's hardly a negative, since the intensity of espresso is, after all, subjective. The Atmosphere For once, this is a suburban coffee shop that is actually comfortable and has a hint of urban dinge that in my opinion, all the best coffee shops have. Sometimes, the dingier the better. The deep yellow-gold, black, copper and dark wood mix well to form a comfortable and inspiring atmosphere. Armed with a great comfy-couch area and plenty of tables (including outside seating) you definitely have your choice of places to sit. Mine, however, was by the fireplace. And that's enough about the design, I drink coffee, after all. The End Finally, the experience was punctuated by genuinely nice staff. I've been a few times, and even Bot1 has sneaked over there a couple times when I haven't been looking. Witty small talk and a staff that calls you by name on the second visit is a good step in the direction of having a lasting neighborhood coffee shop.END [mappress mapid="3"]

item.title: Common Grounds Coffee House
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="2.5" cat1detail="Care is taken in preparation, but overall espresso quality seems to be lacking." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3.5" cat2detail="Lot's of seating, power outlets, local art, bright and natural light."]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicPay ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
1550 17th Street, Denver (LoDo Location) (303) 296-9248
Website
It was a quiet day. A little bored, Bot1 insisted we consult my very-cute-coffee-name-pun list to see if something piqued our interest, and it was then we decided on Common Grounds Coffee House. While usually passionate about the coffee (passion being one of Bot1's few emulated emotions), Bot1 was more interested in reading “Death Beam”, a title he'd spotted on the bookshelf, and while I always try to discourage him reading anything with “death” in it, I decided to pick my battle and allow it. Bot1 then marched up to the counter, emitted his demand for a whole milk latte and a double espresso, beamed the book off the shelf, and proceeded to process the pages via his OCR scanner. The Coffee. As usual, I was left with the coffee. The person who made the drinks was extremely friendly (bonus) and after a pleasant interaction about the weather she proceeded to focus in on the latte. I noticed she took much care when steaming the milk and while I couldn't see the shots as they were extracted, the aroma was enticing and the shots were swiftly combined with the milk. I was given the latte which embodied thick, dense foam, slight hints of brown espresso swirled through the mix, and a warmth that was comforting on that chilly day. Ultimately, however, the flavor, while it didn't disappoint, was only average. To be certain, it was a good latte—one I would return for—but once again the reality was that to have truly impressive beverages, the coffee itself must be spectacular, and it just wasn't. The double espresso disappointed slightly as well. The crema was thin and nearly immediately broke to reveal the dark body of the shot. The“raining” effect or separation of the shot was reminiscent of Guinness, which, as luck would have it, is served at Common Grounds as well. The flavor didn't go deep enough either. The initial stark bitterness never really left my tongue and the acidity was slightly overwhelming, so much so that any dimension that might have been there was masked by this intensity. The Atmosphere. Common Grounds embodied a balanced mix of the old and new. The counter and bar were your typical curvy-bistro-coolness with lots of angles thrown in that made for exciting visuals. There was plenty of room to sprawl out on one of their two very large tables, or keep to yourself on any one of their abundant four-seaters. One feature Bot1 and I liked a lot was the presence of bookshelves with actual physical books. On top of that, if one so desired, one could pick up and read...one. During my visit I did notice a young guy in skinny pants with his Mac under his arm stroking his chin in silent wonder at the spectacle of these books, but for the most part people knew what to do with them. Large windows overlooking the busy street allowed generous amounts of light in, illuminating the local art canvases aiding in a vibrant feel; and the constant murmur of machines, music, and conversation were all at the perfect level. The End. Common Grounds Coffee House withstands the test. Sure, I wasn't bowled over by the coffee, but in the end it was good. Combined with the atmosphere and friendliness of the employees, it's definitely a place you should check out. Bot1 agrees and also informed me “Death Beam” didn't live up to his planet domination aspirations...much to my relief.END [mappress mapid="4"]

item.title: Folsom St. Coffee Company
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="2.5" cat1detail="Utilitarian coffee perfect for those all-night-ers." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3" cat2detail="Couches, bar and tables abound; lots of windows."]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
1795 Folsom St., Boulder, CO 80302 (303) 440-8808
Website
Bot1 had just completed a lecture at CU on the intricacies of wiring a common household goldfish, and like he is after every lecture, found his system needing a certain caffeine boost. We found ourselves at Folsom St. Coffee Co. This is a college joint through and through, and the day we visited it was its usual self: packed, hip...and green. According to their website, Folsom St. Coffee is “Boulder's only true eco-friendly coffeehouse. Folsom St. Coffee Co. was awarded the Eco-Cycle award for 'Zero Waste or Darn Near' as well as the "Waste Reduction" award from the Center For Resource Conservation.” I believe it, because when Bot1 tried to throw away his trash, his waste eliminating algorithm caused his CPU to overheat just trying to sort out which tub to throw what in. The Coffee. As has become customary, a double espresso was ordered and Bot1 left to talk up a couple students who were sitting outside. The espresso presented to me had a deceivingly beautiful thick crema that held fast when I spooned some sugar on top. That was a good sign. The flavor, however, was a disappointment. Oddly enough I felt like I was drinking a lime. Of course there were most of the typical espresso qualities, but the acidity was shocking! I'd like to attribute this to the extraction of the shot, but I watched it pour and everything was on the up and up. The flavor evened out when it was in an Americano, but overall I wasn't too impressed with the flavor. The Atmosphere.Like many coffee shops, however, the experience doesn't always center around the coffee, and ultimately Folsom St. Coffee delivered in other areas. The atmosphere was welcoming, cozy and was the sort of place in which I felt I could get motivated to finally write my 20 page single-spaced essay on the relationship between Pyongyang and Beijing. The muddled and haphazard decor actually cemented the cozy feeling, and that constant murmur of a packed coffee house was ideal for working, meeting friends, or simply sipping a cup of coffee. Complete with poetry, open mic nights and live music acts, this place is hopping a good part of every day, and the sort of place young hipsters like to frequent. The End. Overall this coffee shop is very enjoyable, and despite being turned down three whole times, Bot1 vowed it wouldn't keep him down and will definitely return. While the coffee didn't bowl me over, if you keep it to lattes, Americanos, teas and brews you won't be disappointed. END [mappress mapid="6"]

item.title: Jet's Espressoria
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="4" cat1detail="Killer, well-crafted coffee" cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3.5" cat2detail="Vibrant and unassuming"]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
2116 Pearl Street, Boulder, CO 80302 (303) 247-0124
“Espressoria” is in the name, why wouldn't you go there? I discovered this place while trying to go to another coffee shop that was completely packed. Bot1 has no patience for traffic or mobs of people, and when confronted with such situations, his programmed reaction is to drive 30 mph over the speed limit in one direction--stopping for no one. That's even more dangerous considering the amount of college students and left-over hippies riding around on bicycles in this town. Had he not erupted in such acutely emulated anger, we would never have stumbled across Jet's Espressoria—quaintly situated slightly off the beaten path in Boulder, Colorado. The Coffee. An Americano was ordered, and it was presented to me in a mug and with a beautiful golden crema. As I sipped it, my mouth was filled with a wonderful rich, dense, and full-bodied flavor. It was exactly what I needed after riding in a Subaru with a crazed robot. The flavor held, and over the course of my stay the taste never turned extremely acidic, like some coffees tend to do as they cool. This was the work of a fine roast, great espresso skills, and a wonderful espresso machine. Based on a tweet from back in July, they serve Box Car Espresso, Novo Espresso, and Boulder Organic Espresso. For any of you who have read my other posts, you know you usually have me at “Novo”. Judging from the extremely steady stream of customers, they all agreed with the quality as well. The Atmosphere. This place has a very local, neighborhood, some might say “indie” feel. I interpreted a loose 50's vibe underscored by photographs of abandoned Route 66-style motels and gas stations, retro-looking tables and chairs and swirling ceiling fans. On the face of it, I personally am not a fan of this kind of look for a coffee shop, but I found myself quite comfortable and Bot1 felt he was among kin, being that most of his metal body work originated from the 50's. It also had the dinge (which I'm beginning to think is a word I made up) factor I love so much: sketchy paint jobs, cluttered bar and counter, uneven tables and hand-written signs. It was also filled with the bicycle riding naturalists, designers, and college students that Bot1 nearly annihilated on the way over. In short, a great mix of people. Jet's Espressoria also bills itself as a bakery and their presentation of fine items was not lacking. Because of their $5 minimum for credit card use, I ordered a blueberry muffin as well. When I do these reviews I'm well aware that I am merely taking a snapshot of an overall experience and I allow quite a bit for less-than-great food, drink, or atmosphere, but this blueberry muffin was, well, not great. That said, I noticed most people going for their assortment of quiches and breakfast burritos which all looked wonderful, and next time I visit I will be digging in to one of these for sure. The End. Overall this place was a killer find. The coffee quality is way up there and I am very willing to overlook the muffin disappointment in light of the fine coffee and atmosphere. The employees (owners?) were very friendly and seemed genuinely focused on providing an outstanding product. Bring cash or buy lots of stuff since they have a $5 charge minimum, and try it! END [mappress mapid="7"]

item.title: Illegal Grounds
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="2.5" cat1detail="Utilitarian coffee: drinkable but nothing special." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3" cat2detail="Cozy living room feel but with a good amount of seating."]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholNo Live MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiAutomatic Espresso Machine
925 East 17th Avenue, Denver, CO 80202 (720) 434-0434
No website
Bot1 insisted on Illegal Grounds in Denver's Uptown neighborhood this time around. He insisted because he is convinced anything with the word “Illegal” in it has to be awesome. If you remember back to his reading of “Death Beam” a few posts ago, you know that I try to discourage anything that might be violent or illegal...or involve the word “death”. He may be a caffeine-converted robot, but there is no escaping what he was originally built for. However, I digress. Illegal Grounds, despite its name which implies a certain badness coupled with scary tattoos (or maybe the fact it was started by a lawyer?), is a very tame and inviting neighborhood coffee shop. Situated on the ground floor of an old Victorian house, it embodies all the charms of a local favorite. Upon entrance, you walk straight down a hallway to the counter, and in my case, was met by a very friendly employee. The Coffee. An Americano was ordered and with it in hand, I turned the corner, entered the living room, and flopped down on one of the couches. Ultimately, I wasn't going to expect much from the cup of coffee. The machine was automatic and they serve Illy coffee. Whenever I experience this kind of scenario, this usually translates to a very tame, albeit drinkable, cup of coffee. And I was right. There were no overwhelming flavors or distinctions to the espresso, just utilitarian goodness. I know I sound snooty when I immediately dismiss a beverage produced from an automatic machine, especially since this blog is called "Coffee Bot" which implies a certain level of automation, but understand that ultimately it is the human element in the creation of a beverage that gives it its ultimate dimension and uniqueness. It's that human element that fuels my passion for exceptional coffee. The Atmosphere. The atmosphere didn't disappoint. Once I rounded the corner into the seating area (or living room), I was immediately impressed with how many tables and chairs could fit amid the cozy space. A large picture window at the end of the room gave a bright, framed view of 17th street, and the light that poured in lit the walls full of local art. Wood floors, quiet music and a plentiful supply of power strips made Illegal Grounds a perfect spot to hunker down and get straight to conversation, work, or relaxation. Take note: this place was pretty quiet despite the small crowd. To that end, if you are going to discuss the party habits of fellow world leaders and don't want your secrets ending up on Wikileaks, this might not be the right place for those conversations. Alternatively, you could sit outside on the covered porch-there are far less people there. The End. Even though Bot1 didn't fit easily between the tables and chairs, I would say our visit was a success and we will definitely return. The coffee gets the job done, the employees were very friendly, and the atmosphere makes you want to hang around a little longer than you might at another coffee shop. END [mappress mapid="8"]

item.title: La Dolce Vita
item.dc:creator: Bot6
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="2.5" cat1detail="Utilitarian coffee: drinkable but nothing special." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="2" cat2detail="Tidy and worn but friendly."]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
5756 Olde Wadsworth Blvd, Arvada, CO 80002 (303) 456-8919
Website
After browsing the local shops of Olde Town Arvada for spools of copper wire (I didn’t ask), Bot1 and I decided to stop in La Dolce Vita for a restorative cuppa. On first impression, this shop appears tidy, but worn and outdated—rather like your kitschy great-aunt’s 80s-tastic pastel dining room. The marble and cast-iron tables, though, are wonderfully stable for writing, playing chess, etc. (I scoff at Bot2’s affinity for wobbly furniture). The place was almost awkwardly quiet, but we were glad that there were only a handful of other early afternoon customers because the single barista, though rather adept at latte art, operated the manual espresso machine fairly slowly. In dealing with customers—including our delightful selves and some who were more than a little obnoxious—she upheld La Dolce Vita’s claim of being “Arvada’s friendliest coffeehouse,” without seeming overly pushy or fake. The Coffee. La Dolce Vita offers a pretty extensive selection of teas, espresso, and syrup flavors, as well as breakfast items and pastries, but I settled on a small americano (12oz. = $2.20). The espresso was very mild and smooth—perfectly adequate for a quick boost after shopping, though not a lot to savor. This shop does run specials (e.g. $1.75 lattes after 2pm) and provides a loyalty card to allow regulars to earn a free drink, which is always a plus in my rather sparse pocketbook. The Atmosphere. There were plenty of tables inside (and a handful on the sidewalk outside), so we choose a semi-private spot in the bay window. The general lack of outlets in this area seemed to distress Bot1 on principle, but I appreciated that the laptop creeper who wanted to share our table had to sit across the room (I imagine he couldn’t help gravitating toward bots, though I’ve resolved to practice looking unsavory). The End. If you go, a note of warning: there is a step from the café seating area down to the counter. For some reason, the glaring yellow signs warning me to watch my step proved difficult to read while I was falling on my face. In addition, La Dolce Vita plays host to a variety of local live music performances on most Saturdays, including the occasional “open mic night.” The music begins around 7pm, but if you want a seat, get there before the locals crowd in. END [mappress mapid="9"]

item.title: Crema Coffee House
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="5" cat1detail="5 stars not given lightly, the proof is in the cup." cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3.5" cat2detail="Underground and industrial."]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholNo MusicFree ParkingNo FoodFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
2862 Larimer, Denver, CO 80205 (720) 235-2995
Website
Prelude. For those of you who have read my previous reviews, you may have noticed that when ever I am describing the coffee, I almost always remark on the crema. I do this because the crema is the soul of the espresso. Without it you are simply confronted with a dark and formless beverage that leaves you hovering over the face of some sort of liquid void. Crema contains the flavorful, complex, and oily soul of the espresso shot. It's the lifeblood and excitement of coffee itself. That said, when Bot1 discovered an entire coffee shop named after this beauty, it was a no-brainer, or in Bot1's case, a no-CPUer that we check it out. Everything this shop does, it does well. The website, branding, interior design and ultimately, the coffee are nothing short of stellar. Bot1 is programmed to respond to excellence by demanding we go back again, and again, and again since it triggers an infinite system loop. Right off the bat, I'd recommend you do the same. The Coffee. As we entered Crema (nestled in the Five Points area, or NoDo) I was struck by the overall simplicity and itty-bitty-ness of the place. The counter is no more than four paces from the front door and the menu is purposefully sparse—not only in its lack of fluff beverages but also in the fact that it is printed on the wall. It was immediately apparent the owner is a purist. For instance, this is not the shop for suburban frappu-whatever drinkers. Crema offers only three flavors: mocha, vanilla and caramel. It's the equivalent to restoring peace to the world by neutralizing one coffee-assassinating flavor at a time. However, other than the occasional mocha, I don't flavor my coffee, therefore my Americano was ordered. The lever was pulled, the shots were extracted, and the drink slid across the counter to me. The liquid rocked easily back and forth in the ceramic with the thick crema surface holding together tightly reflecting deep, red-brown and golden swirls. It glistened with the oily coffee bean residue (crema is the only time 'oil' and 'residue' are good things as descriptors), hinting at the flavor that was to come. Butter, caramel, crisp acidity and subtle bitterness filled my taste buds and for the first time in a very long time, I savored every single ounce of that Americano. (It's at this point I should mention the espresso was a Novo roast. Sound familiar? Other roasters who make an appearance at Crema are Herkimer and Pablo's- according to the website, that is.) The Atmosphere is what it is. Clearly underground, it is cold, utilitarian and industrial with a few reclaimed odds and ends. The tables and chairs have that certain retro flair, and I'm pretty sure they are original stuff, not overpriced re-makes. Hip below-ground art adorned the brick/plaster walls when I first visited, and the room was quite bright thanks to a fairly large red-pained window in the front. I had a bit of trouble finding an outlet for my laptop and finally found one behind a couch, but I noticed plenty of people on their Macs not bothered by this who apparently have risen above the need for a plug. Who needs an outlet, though? This is the sort of place you go to sip your velvety microfoam and discuss bands that don't exist yet, not necessarily type up your doctoral thesis. There is a tiny bar that you can belly up to and watch the Baristas fashion their creations, and overall, considering the square footage, there is a good amount of seating for the size. Finally, a few points to note: First, you don't go there if you are in a rush. It's obvious the owner is more interested in the beverage quality than in the fact you forgot to set your alarm, spent too much time watching Kardashians reruns and are now running late for work. Every drink is made one-at-a time which maximizes quality but not speediness. In fact, if you are ordering a latte or cappuccino, each will include some sort of latte design, even if you are slapping a lid on it. Second, Crema's muffins are insanely good and as a bonus they don't have the paper wrapper around the bottom so you don't have to peel it off. Let me tell you, this is reason enough to go there! Finally, they have a great selection of fine teas, but that review is up to TeaBot, not me, and TeaBot doesn't even exist...yet. The End In conclusion: go there. No excuses, just go. You won't regret it. [mappress mapid="10"]

[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

item.title: Coffee & Tea, War & Peace
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded: I recently discovered Google's Ngram Viewer and found it really fascinating. For those of you who haven't experienced the sheer excitement of this sort of thing, I'll briefly explain: Google has digitized millions of books and made every word of them search-able, so when you type in a certain word, you can see how often that word has shown up in literature through the course of history. Of course, after punching in all the usual suspects: war, peace; male, female; Coke, Pepsi; I punched in coffee and tea. The graph acted a little like I thought it might with tea being fairly dominant for most of history. Both examples rise with the spread of literature and books for the people, but I noticed the rise and fall of these words seem to coincide with fairly big historical events. Anyone remember the Boston Tea Party? I am curious then, what other big coffee and tea historical events might be reflected on the graph? For those of you who are A) more knowledgeable of history than I am, and B) more knowledgeable of coffee than I am, I'd love to read what you think. And hop over to Google's Ngram site, it's a lot of fun! [caption id="attachment_472" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Coffee and Tea Ngram from 1600 to now"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_476" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Ngram of Coffee & Tea in the 20th century"][/caption]

item.title: Paul's Coffee & Tea
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="3.5" cat1detail="Coffee roasted on the spot makes for a good cup" cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="2.5" cat2detail="Pleasant, 'folky' and bright "]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
956 West Cherry, Louisville, CO 80027 (720) 259-1723
Website
Bot1 and I arrived at Paul's Coffee and Tea, a modest coffee shop located in the commercial and professional area of Louisville, Colorado. Since Louisville consistently ranks in the top places to live in the US year after year (Proof), you expect its businesses to perform to a somewhat higher standard. Ultimately, this place does. True to the culture of the area, all the coffee served and roasted is fair trade and organic, caters to hippies and yuppies alike, has a very friendly staff, and owns its fair share of potted plants. Paul's is definitely a place worth stopping in, and the added incentive for me is the fact they roast their own coffee. The roaster, positioned [strategically] close to the front door, greets you with the smokey-sweet aroma of roasted beans, an aroma that you hit like a wall upon entrance. The Coffee. True to form, a double espresso was ordered and Bot1 set to processing the menu's unique price points (2.77 for a latte, for instance). At the first sip I was happy to taste a wonderfully balanced extraction with slight berry notes and a clean acidity. Translated, it was good. Bot1, who'd ordered a Mocha, let me share a bit of his which was also very good. He quickly snatched it back, however, since whipped cream offers one of the few excitements he gets to experience in his emulated life. This means the espresso holds its own on its own, or as the foundation to the assortment of espresso-based drinks. The Atmosphere. The atmosphere draws you in with its simplicity folky charm. The entire east, north, and west walls are actually windows which offer peeks toward the Flatirons and rich sunlight that's very warm in the winter but slightly too warm in the summer. The folk theme carries through with bluegrass instruments, country nick knacks, decrepit windows as wall art, and even a moonshine jug that Bot1 was entirely convinced was full of moonshine. It's the sort of place you'd expect to find tucked back in the pines of the Rockies. Local art rotates fairly often and is always a good variety. There is a decent amount of tables and chairs and along the windows are a few power strips to plug your lifestyle in to. Be prepared to share a table with someone if you absolutely need an outlet though, since there isn't a huge selection of tables along the windows. The End. With daily specials, customer loyalty punch cards, coffee by the press, happy hour, decent prices (even if they are a bit odd), perks if you donate to a charity and Saturday Bluegrass concerts, Paul's definitely gives you plenty of reasons to return and get in touch with your country-coffee side. END [mappress mapid="11"]

[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

item.title: Trident Booksellers and Cafe
item.dc:creator: Bot6
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="4" cat1detail="Serious & Sexy" cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="4" cat2detail="Artistically hip and comfortably welcoming"]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicPaid ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
Mon - Sat 6:30am - 11:00pm
Sun 7:00am - 11:00pm
940 Pearl St., Boulder, CO 80304 303.443.3133
Website
Confession: I, Bot6, have an irrational (possibly unhealthy) obsession with those archaic bits of paper sewn together and marketed to hopeless nostalgics as “books.” Bot1 recommends a program upgrade to digital browsing, but I am nothing if not stubborn. I dragged Bot1 into Trident’s bookstore, leading him through the cozy nooks and tall shelves crammed with leather-bound covers and musty paperbacks, but he still doesn’t “get me.” Fortunately, Trident hosts an adjoining café that nearly always draws customers in with a delightful aroma of coffee, chai spice, and peppermint (those who are familiar with the general Eau de Boulder—a tantalizing mix of hung-over co-eds, stale doobies, and unwashed hippies—will appreciate this triumph). The Coffee. Bot1 mumbled something about “intervention,” as he dragged me away from the brink of purchasing a fourth copy of Paradise Lost to the café counter. Though I’ve spent many an afternoon enjoying Trident’s artsy/cozy atmosphere, this was the first time I ordered coffee. Until today, I’d been systematically working my way through their wall of loose-leaf tea options (which they serve with a mug and a tiny personal tea pot), but I sensed Bot1 evaluating our friendship after my book-ogling, so I decided to follow his lead and order an Americano ($2.20). The barista was friendly, without forcing an artificial chattiness, and served my beautiful drink in a beer glass (the other option was a darling thimble-cup that would have left even Barbie with a severe case of caffeine deprivation). The glass showcased a beautiful crema; I hadn’t seen an Americano this sexy since I made them myself. I added a few drops of milk, but I needn’t even have done that. Trident’s espresso is smooth and well-balanced, while still maintaining a hearty richness, though some might prefer a “boulder” taste (hahaha—get it? “Boulder?” No? Oh, fine). The Atmosphere. We carried our drinks past rows of local photography displays (and a toasty woodstove) to the back of the café, where we fortunately found an empty booth. Though usually busy, Trident doesn’t seem to draw the typical student/tourist set. Instead, its location at the west end of Pearl St., and the fact that it has been around for over 20 years, attracts the local community—professors, grad students, environmentalists, business-owners, etc. The back patio sports a sand-box, so beware children. And pigeons. Inside, the storefront windows, exposed brick walls, and high ceiling create a comfortably bright atmosphere, although it can be slightly dark at night. Also, I fear our booth’s last occupant was a tamed wildebeest, judging from the gaping bum-crater in the seat cushion. Even perching on the crater’s ample rim, I needed a phone book to reach the table properly, which was bolted to the wall so that I also had to reach forward to scribble my notes. I recommend a regular table. The End. Overall, Trident has perfected the balance between artistically hip and comfortably welcoming—like your impossibly cool, non-elitist friend who loves you despite your nerdy tendencies and bad puns. END [mappress mapid="12"]

item.title: Make Good Coffee at Home: French Press Style
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[ad#Google Adsense Post Ad]

I know, we can all find our favorite coffee shop to get that essential coffee fix, and for a lot of people, it's also tons better than what they prepare at home. This is especially the case for the majority of brewed coffee drinkers out there. Preparing excellent coffee at home is not really that hard; it's also not really that time consuming. With the right tools and the right ingredients you can rival anything you find in a coffee shop. Look, If you are completely okay with coffee that comes from a plastic tub or out of the machine at 7-11, this post probably won't mean much to you. If, however, you want that quality cup but don't want to spend the $2 every day, or you want to impress your guests with killer coffee and dessert, this just might help you out. The rest of this post assumes you are striving for excellence every time you make coffee in your casa. The Tools... For every project, you have to have the right tools to get the job done well. For this post, we'll be making coffee via French press, so, here's what you'll need:
  • French press
  • grinder: blade or burr
  • kettle
The Ingredients...
  • whole bean coffee
  • filtered water
Water is Key! First off, your coffee is only as good as your water! The number one important element of good coffee is water! Think about it: coffee is 98% H2O, so if your water tastes bad, chances are your coffee will as well even if you are using $50/lb coffee. You don't have to have an expensive reverse osmosis system to achieve good water; a simple water filtering pitcher, or even bottled drinking water will do the trick. The Coffee. Okay, for (good) coffee beans, I recommend you pop down to your local coffee shop and purchase a half or full pound of beans. Don't know what to get? Just ask, they are usually more than willing to chat and help you pick a roast. Shops often sell what they serve, so if there is a particular brew you really enjoy, grab a pound of that. It is also possible to find good beans in the grocery store, but it's a little harder and you don't really know if it's good or not until you try it. Here's a tip: in my experience, anything labeled with the generic descriptor “gourmet”  is a complete flop and I would avoid it like the plague. The same goes when I visit a restaurants and cafes. Most self-respecting roasters and coffee shops no longer use this term. Grind Your Coffee As You Go This may seem like quite a burden each time you make coffee, but here's why you want to grind as you go: once coffee has been roasted, oxygen becomes its mortal enemy and immediately the flavors in the oils begin to evaporate and the bean begins to sour. This is why coffee beans arrive in air-tight packages protected from all that nasty oxygen. Furthermore, when you grind coffee, you compromise the flavor's 'housing' and add more surface area for the beans to spoil, giving the ground coffee a very, very short shelf life. For the richest flavor, only purchase as much coffee as you will drink in a week, keep it sealed in its original package or a canister, and grind as you go. Side note: don't keep your beans in the fridge or freezer. Doing this doesn't prolong its life; in fact,  the coffee absorbs all those lovely refrigerator aromas (expired-potato-salad-pong-flavored Kona, anyone?). Keep the beans in a sealed container at room temperature and your coffee will stay its most flavorful and least corrupted. Proportion. This depends on you and your taste buds, actually, but a general rule is one tablespoon per cup. A lot of places talk about proportions in grams, but not too many of us have an accurate kitchen scale laying around, so forget that. A typical French press holds 8 cups of liquid, therefore use 8 tbs. If I'm in an economical mood I sometimes do 7 tbs to 8 cups, but any less than that would leave your coffee tasting pretty watered down. You can increase it a bit if you really want an intense flavor, but I wouldn't go more than 1 or 2 tablespoons over that or the flavor will be uncomfortably intense. Temperature (Water again). Get that water hot! An electric kettle works great if you have one, but use some method of boiling your water, even if it's in a saucepan. The target temp is around 200 degrees Fahrenheit, so right after the water hits a boil let it settle down, and then pour it into the press making sure to saturate all the grounds. Caution: don't burn the coffee! The flavor is extracted from the beans best around the 200 degree mark. If the water is any hotter, the coffee will taste over-extracted (bitter) and burnt. Time it! It's really important for the coffee and water to mix promiscuously allowing the oils to saturate and brew. 4 minutes allows this to be accomplished. If you are really striving for that cup of perfection, pour the water evenly over the grounds and fill the press a quarter full. Let the grounds then sit for a minute and “bloom”--then at the end of the minute, add the rest of the water and stir. If you don't want to do that, just pour the water in all at once and give it a good stir. Plunge it! When four minutes are up, drive all the grounds to the bottom with the plunger. In most cases the plunger screens the grounds so that they don't get into your cup. If you do get a couple, have no fear, they are not out to get you. Drink it! Enjoy this beautiful beverage! So does this seem like a lot of work? Let's think about it: depending on the elevation where you live, it takes somewhere around 2 to 4 minutes for water to boil. During that time I grab all my stuff: the press (I make sure it's clean), grind the coffee, add it to the press, grab my cups, etc. and by the time everything is together the water is ready. I pour, and I set my timer to 4 minutes. You can do the math; it's about six to eight minutes from start to finish. That's just about the same time as a conventional brewer. Below is a video you can watch to see how easy it really is. Enjoy :)

French Press Style from Christan Fergus on Vimeo.

item.title: Fluid Coffee Bar
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="3.75" cat1detail="The right ingredients for good coffee" cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3.5" cat2detail="inspirational and chill"]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
Mon - Fri 6:30am-10:00pm
Sat - Sun 7:00am-10:00pm
501 E 19th Ave, Denver, CO 80203 720.519.4681
Website
A friend mentioned a place in uptown Denver that was attempting to re-define the coffee shop experience. “Redefine, eh?”. This is a place I had to visit. “Redefine(ing)” can be dangerous. Bot1 once tried to redefine rock. That's how the world got prog-rock. Hopefully the coffee shop 'redefinement' turns out a bit better. Bot1 was also excited to visit since there were computers he could use instead of relying on his 28k on-board modem to download 25 minute drum solos. So, we headed for the shop and arrived barely out of the shadows of downtown's skyscrapers in an uncomfortably sterile neighborhood of condos and street shops. My first impression of the place was positive and not at all what I expected after checking the shop's website (which doesn't do the place any justice). It was packed with city peeps when we arrived and I wound my way through tables and urbanites to the counter where I was welcomed by a large overhead menu and a not so welcoming, too-cool-for-school barista. The Coffee. I ordered a double espresso ($1.80) and Bot1 went for the mocha (medium:$3.50). The espresso was presented in a demitasse and I couldn't wait to have my first sip. Once again, I stumbled on a place serving Novo coffee and was eager to see how it emerged from the machine. The first sip flashed with a bright acidity that yielded a complex cluster of flavors reminding me a bit of peanut butter—I was happy. It wasn't the best espresso I've had but as the foundation to the rest of the beverages it was quality nonetheless. The mocha was fairly good as well (I sneaked a sip while Bot1 configured his IP address) although it was a bit sweet. It's also worth noting that this truly is a good place for the coffee aficionado since I saw numerous french presses and am pretty sure some pourover coffee magic. The Atmosphere. What really makes Fluid Coffee tick is what I mentioned in the beginning of this post: coffee shop 'redefinement-ation-ing'. There is an abundance of places to sit, relax, work, and plug in. This is no internet cafe of the old days when shifty old guys hovered over bulky computers that were crammed against the walls of dingy, fluorescent-lit rooms sipping over-extracted, stale coffee. Instead you have flat panels, windows (so you're not completely cut off from the world), shifty lawyers instead of shifty old guys, and superb coffee. Okay, I concede a bit of redefining. Fluid coffee has filled every nook with something for the customer: books, magazines, art, computers, and a [new] room full of tables that you can reserve for yourself or your team. You also don't have to be without those office amenities if you are working remotely. For a fee, you are able to print and copy your top secret documents or the next great American novel. There is even a large column right next to the counter plastered with adverts and business cards so you can get ye-self out there and get discovered. Finally, I found the atmosphere fairly inspirational: multicolored walls, comfortable seating, clutter, conversational murmur, and a diversity of patrons did well to get the juices flowing. It's the sort of place Bot1 and I can fit in with no brow-raising—it's truly a neighborhood coffee shop. The End. So, does it redefine the coffee shop experience? They certainly make it easy for the incognito professional to have place to work, serve outstanding coffee, and manage to do all this without being a creepy internet cafe. Fluid coffee has found a great mix of community, casual, and professional. At the same time, it's still only a coffee shop: one that neither wowed or excited me, but one that I most definitely will recommend to others and visit again...and again. END [mappress mapid="13"]

item.title: Buchanan’s Coffee Pub
item.dc:creator: Bot6
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="2" cat1detail="Not Incredible" cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="2" cat2detail="Summed up: college-ness"]
Features (Key) No ATMNo AlcoholLive MusicPaid ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
1301 Pennsylvania Ave, Boulder, CO 80302 303.440.0222
I’d love to describe in vivid detail the décor of Buchanan’s Coffee Pub, but my initial impression was only of stale incense swirling amongst a wall of undergrads. Fortunately, Bot1 tends to swear in binary, or I’m certain we would have been kicked out before paying for our coffee (12 oz. Americano= $2.22). Fighting through the crowd, we claimed the only available table—on the patio, next to an enthusiastic dance major (aside: we soon learned that “super” has worked its way back into the English vernacular with a vengeance, at which point Bot1 nearly short-circuited). Buchanan’s patio flanks the front door, facing west toward the busy intersection of Pennsylvania and Broadway, and the University of Colorado. This arrangement creates a prime basking/people-watching location in the afternoon, but if you forget your sun block, you’ll be the proud owner of a highly awkward “half-face sunburn.” There’s a lot to see, as “the hill” is home to many strange creatures, including (but not limited to) religious recruiters, social advocates, and various strains of hippie. In addition, an unfortunately gangly “sk8rboi” in lime green “jeggings” is forever imprinted on my mind—I wish I were kidding. Those who insist on conversing above the ruckus eventually resort to shouting and, consequently, must suffer the judgment of the other customers (I dedicate this paragraph to the table of passionate poli-sci majors who were laboring under the communal delusion that the opinions they were shouting at one another were, somehow, different. But I digress). The Coffee Buchanan’s either servers Silver Canyon coffee or they stole their cups. Regardless, the espresso is medium-light, with a slightly bitter aftertaste (even with a touch of cream in it). My Americano was neither amazing nor unique, but having tasted the brown sludge for sale in the UMC, it’s worth the trek across campus. In addition to coffee, Buchanan’s sells pastries, gluten-free snacks, bagels, and (curiously) fair-trade crafts and jewelry. The Atmosphere Eventually, a horde of people vacated the café lobby and Bot1 and I moved inside. I’d have to call Buchanan’s atmosphere “manufactured urban.” Local artwork and framed music posters decorate the walls, interspersed with intentionally exposed brick. Dozens of outlets run along the counters on three walls, which means that students (and visitors from the Boulder International Hostel just down the street) will move in here for hours at a time (the on-line printer and free-wifi probably add to the appeal). It’s bright, and the bluegrass/folk music sets a nice tone, but so many tables cram together that customers are constantly in each other’s conversations (this might be fine for some, but Bot1 jumped in uninvited with “Heidegger, Derrida, and a duck walk into a bar . . .”). The EndThere is paid parking in the lot across the street, or at meters along the block (beware parking in the adjacent neighborhoods, or you might find yourself the proud owner of 2 parking tickets—in the same envelope, no less!). In addition, there are a couple bike racks out front, but judging from the many bikes chained to every railing along the street, these aren’t quite adequate for the demand. I highly recommend visiting this café in the summer, when Boulder’s population decreases by about 20, 000. END [mappress mapid="14"]

item.title: Cafe de Paris
item.dc:creator: bot2
item.content:encoded:
[easyreview title="The Stats" cat1title="Coffee Quality" cat1rating="4" cat1detail="Good coffee done well" cat2title="Atmosphere" cat2rating="3" cat2detail="cluttered artsy charm"]
Features (Key) No ATMAlcoholLive MusicFree ParkingFood is ServedFree WifiManual Espresso Machine
908 Main Street, Louisville, CO 80027 303.665.9761
Mon - Fri 6:30am - 9:00pm
Sat 9:00am - 9:00pm
Sun 10:00am - 3:00pm
Website
Bot1 was bored and complaining that he hadn't exercised his french algorithms in a while and they needed flexing. I tried to disagree by making the point French algorithms should just stay where they are, but after warning me he'd actually move to France if I didn't let him, I traipsed him down to Cafe de Paris in Old Town(e) Louisville, Colorado to get it out of his system. As one might expect, I figured this place was just another “in name only” joint that really had nothing to do with Paris at all (not that I'm an authority on the city). I was right, well, almost. When we walked in we were met with the croonings of a geeky jazz quartet—and for a brief moment it did indeed feel like a Paris cafe in the fifties. Or it at least felt like I've seen them portrayed in the movies. This was a nice surprise, and Bot1 approved so we decided to stay. The Coffee I edged around the double bass and did my best to remember my high school french. When I realized I couldn't remember any of it, I ordered my coffee (in English) and took a corner table nestled under a bohemian lamp and beside a large picture window overlooking the bustling street. Once again, we'd stumbled on yet another shop serving Novo roasted coffee, which indicated off-the-bat that the desire for quality was present. And indeed, upon my first sip, that was the case. Full dimension, balanced flavor and lingering sweetness characterized the nectar that emerged from the Rancilio manual espresso machine. The Atmosphere I was very comfortable sitting in this comfortably-cramp shop. The evening was warm and the sidewalk seating appealed to me, but Bot1 insisted we sit inside, and if you are a frequent reader of these posts, you know he gets his way. Six round tables fit where only four should go, but somehow it worked and I didn't feel too claustrophobic. Perhaps it was the Bohemian flavor from the painted walls to the paintings on the walls, or the Victorian lamp shades, or all of these, but it was definitely the kind of place I could spend some time. In fact, you could get really comfortable for a long time since beer and wine are also served. I love coffee shops that do this—you've got all the bases covered. The shop definitely goes lengths to have that European vibe, down to elements you can't necessarily control. Such as the hipster clientele who, as Bot1 and I sat and sipped our coffees and tapping our toes and metallic phalanges to the music, sketched and painted meaningful and earnest doodles at their tables. Had we stumbled across a sliver of the Paris art scene, one that stowed away on the Titanic, perhaps, only to be set adrift somehow surfacing upstream in Colorado? Okay, well that's going a little too far, but needless to say it was a fun, and perhaps even inspiring atmosphere to be in. The End Don't let me steer you wrong with my emphasis on coffee side of things, though. These guys are a full on “bistro” serving up a variety of tasty foods and desserts, even for those with slightly more high maintenance diets. I would however steer clear of their pastry items. I've been a few times and each time the bakery good whether a scone or sweet bread was dry almost to the point of stale. Don't spend the money. Aside from that, overall, this cafe does what it should: calms, inspires, satisfies the taste buds, and makes you want to return for more. END [mappress mapid="15"]
